aboutMe.title: About Me
description: I'm a person passionate about software and game development from Buenos Aires, Argentina. Currently working in the world of web development.

My work profile is methodical, following clear and defined rules, focusing on the development of structured, readable, and scalable code. However, this is not a limitation when joining an active team or project, as my analytical skills allow me to adapt to the conditions that arise.
My experience as a supervisor of a development team and as a software architect has also equipped me with human management skills such as morale, delivery deadlines, and assertive communication.
I enjoy contributing to and seeing projects grow in which I participate.

timeline.title: Experience
timeline.description: Here I present a summary of the projects and studies I have undertaken throughout my professional career.

items.title: Personal Fun Projects
description: My initial steps into the programming world. I started by delving into how video games were made, considering technical decisions, and learning programming.
This phase includes various C++ projects where I utilized graphic engines and resources such as sound, textures, and 3D models from other games. I then applied my own logic and created my own levels.

items.title: Independent Web Projects
description: When I began to feel that I wanted to dedicate myself to this, I was certain of one thing: game-related projects were too ambitious, especially for a 17-year-old.

For this reason, and because I also started to be interested in how to apply software solutions to everyday problems in my environment, I became interested in web development. This is where I learned the basics of PHP and JavaScript.
Later, out of curiosity, I ventured into some test projects for mobile and desktop applications, adding Java and Python to my known programming languages.

These projects weren't very complex, nor did they use elaborate libraries. However, I believe this simplicity was an advantage, allowing me to grasp the basics and build a solid foundation in web development.

items.title: Computer Engineering at the University of Buenos Aires
description: Naturally, my next step was to study something related to my interests. Hence, I enrolled in Computer Engineering at the University of Buenos Aires.

At this institution, during my studies, there were no entrance exams. Instead, all students went through a basic academic year known as CBC (Common Basic Cycle) to establish the foundations of the program.
My journey through CBC was challenging due to health issues, but I didn't give up. This was a field I was passionate about, so I decided to continue studying as soon as I could.

As I began taking my first truly informatics-related subjects, I encountered a significant disappointment: the programs were outdated, which led me to situations where I had to continually point out logical errors to professors.
It was at this point that I decided if I were to continue studying this field, it couldn't be at this particular place.

items.title: Independent Full Stack Development
description: Once I believed I had the necessary tools, I embarked on my first professional web development projects. This marked my entry into the deeper technical aspects of web development, such as frameworks, versioning, and various techniques.

Since I was the sole person in charge of the projects I took on, I naturally handled full-stack web development. Though some people may not like this term, I clarify: front-end and back-end web development.
These were my initial professional projects, allowing me to experience tasks like estimating a project, reaching agreements with clients, and working accordingly.

items.title: Introduction to Computer Science from HarvardX
description: In light of the challenges I faced during my Computer Engineering studies at the University of Buenos Aires, I sought alternative learning paths, even if temporarily.

I found this course from Harvard University offered in the 'CS50' program, enrolled, and completed it over a year. While it covered introductory content, and I was familiar with many concepts, it provided a more technical focus on my existing knowledge.

Although I didn't obtain the completion certificate not because I didn't finish it—I did reach completion, but I needed to submit a final project. Unfortunately, due to time constraints, I never submitted it.

items.title: Full Stack Developer at NewBitCrew
description: Convinced that I was ready for more, I joined the NewBitCrew development team as a full-time full-stack developer. Here, I learned and grew significantly, both personally and professionally.

From the beginning, I took on full-stack challenges, responsible for technical and aesthetic design, as well as subsequent development of significant projects. And I occasionally contributed to other projects.
I faced and led complete refactorings and new developments, including technical analysis. Quality, high problem-solving capacity, and teamwork are some aspects I perfected during this phase.

items.title: Front-end Developer at Byter
description: With extra time and a desire for more challenges, I collaborated with Byter as a temporal front-end developer.
During this period, I refined my front-end skills, creating complex web applications, dealing with a large amount of interconnected data, while maintaining a consistent aesthetic.

items.title: Team Lead at NewBitCrew
description: My daily tasks included closely monitoring each developer's progress, overseeing general project status, conducting technical analysis and pending reviews, creating tasks and documentation, providing status reports, continuously interacting with clients, and deploying to various environments. In addition to, of course, development.

I believe being in this position has helped me solidify technical aspects that aren't typically visible as a developer, or at least are seen less frequently. For example, matters of architecture, best practices in development, and dealing with production environments, as well as problem-solving and addressing requests considering variables such as time, client mindset, prior agreements, etc.
Every day I tried to imprint my personal touch on leadership, convey positive energy, boost morale, and take care of the mental health of the team members.

items.title: Software Engineer at Mercado Libre
description: I am currently here, serving as a full-time Software Engineer at Mercado Libre.

future.title: What's next?
future.description: I don't like being idle, and I'm aware of the fast pace of this industry. That's why I'm constantly looking for ways to improve or learn. I'm primarily driven by curiosity or what I find enjoyable to learn, though I also take into account what topics are relevant at the moment.
